Topic.Title: Apple's A6

Message.Msg: I suspect tablets are about to become ubiquitous. Assuming the price points are correct, W8, Ipad, and Android will have tablets around $200-$250, which will move a lot of number crunching to non-intel CPUs. My concern for Intel is gigaflops per dollar. Intel has the best CPUs by a long shot, but they cost $200, while these little ARMs cost ~$20. Data center will be fine, but consumer may be flat. W8 will help, and Intel is already discounted, so who knows.

Topic.Title: ARM Tablets to cost 300 bucks less than Intel Tablets

Message.Msg: An ARM tablet should cost less than a PC tablet because an ARM tablet is just a big smartphone. An application on a smartphone or on an ARM tablet is often just a connection to a website. An Intel tablet with Windows could run applications from Win 3.1 to Win 7. But the computer makers should be very clear that they have an Atom tablet as a consumer model and an Ivy Bridge tablet as a business model.

Topic.Title: Watch Friday near close time. Market maker

Message.Msg: There are very few sites that I find interesting but so far, this one seems have some interesting stuff. I especially like the PUT WRITING sections. I like to write at the money puts (60-90 days out where the price is $1-$1.50) on intel after several big down days. VIX is high, bounce is building up and Intel options are pretty liquid with small spread. The VIX comes down (option price drops), Intel bounces (option price drops) and time value premium decreases (option price drops). Depending on what happens, I cover when they drop to 25 - 50 cents. Site, so far, seems to have some good info. thanks

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: At that point, some analysts predict, Intel’s offerings may become so superior that manufacturers and carriers will have no choice but to switch to them. “The goal is ultimately to get inside Apple,” says Patrick Moorhead, a longtime AMD executive turned analyst. “And Intel will pull out every stop to get there.” This rising tide could also enable more and more connected devices—thermostats, pill-bottle caps, door locks, water heaters—all running tiny, powerful, energy-efficient Intel chips.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: There are plenty of ARM fans who believe that Intel may still stumble in its phone bid—not because of a lack of technical chops but because the inertial pull of its old PC business practices and a dependence on fat margins will trip up the company. Bell has heard all the criticism and brushes it off. Most phone and tablet users don’t care what chip is powering their favorite device—as long as it’s fast and doesn’t drain the battery quickly. “The best product wins,” Bell says. “If we come out with the best products, we deserve to have significant market share.” Or, as a pirate might say, hand over those doubloons.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: Medfield with Intel's process lead is only at par with current ARM offerings on the power-performance map. With the growing manufacturing momentum behind the ARM camp, this is unlikely to change. Otellini's claims on extending the process lead don't check out. Likely scenario -- Intel remains a fringe player in mobile for a while then gracefully exits as it has done on countless projects before this that are outside of its comfort zone. Perhaps growth in cloud processing will keep the machine in motion.

Message.Title: Sep speculation
Message.Msg: I'm buying some INTC Sep28 calls for pennies. The Intel Developers forum is Sep 11-13. This often the time that new Intel products come to light. Paul Ottelini has always made the the opening keynote address at these events. Not this year. The Apple iPhone announcement is rumored to be on Sep 12. Coincidence? Will Ottelini be at the Apple event for some mega announcement? Such as Intel making Apple parts? The options expire Sep 21, plenty of time for a multi-dollar run if any of my above speculation comes true.

"During that period, Marriott engaged in a series of complex and high-profile maneuvers, including 'Son of Boss,' a notoriously abusive prepackaged tax shelter that investment banks and accounting firms marketed to corporations such as Marriott," states the op-ed, which was published this week on CNN.com. The authors –Peter C. Canellos, former chair of the New York State Bar Association Tax Section, and Edward D. Kleinbard, former chief of staff of Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation–wrote that the "Son of Boss" tax shelter marked "perhaps the largest tax avoidance scheme in history" and cost the U.S. "billions in lost corporate tax revenues." While Romney did not face criminal charges, unlike others linked to the scandal, the authors wrote "his endorsement of this stratagem provides insight into Romney's professional ethics and attitude toward tax compliance obligations."

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: The gross margin issue an often repeated myth. Taking QCOM as an example, QCOM's corporate gross margin is 67% and TSMC's corporate gross margin is 45%. Applying these margins to a $30 mobile chip gives a manufacturing cost of $5.45 for an 82% overall gross margin. the same size chip from Intel with a 70% margin would sell to the end user for $18.17. the truth is that the fabless business model is at an extreme cost disadvantage to Intel.

Message.Title: Just a Few Thoughts for You Folks-
Message.Msg: * Never take a beer to a job interview. * Always identify people in your yard before shooting at them. * It's considered tacky to take a cooler to church. * If you have to vacuum the bed, it is time to change the sheets. * Even if you're certain that you are included in the will, it is still considered tacky to drive a U-Haul to the funeral home. * When decanting wine, make sure that you tilt the paper cup, and pour slowly so as not to "bruise" the fruit of the wine. * If drinking directly from the bottle, always hold it with your fingers covering the label. * A centerpiece for the table should never be anything prepared by a taxidermist. * Do not allow the dog to eat at the table...no matter how good his manners are. * While ears need to be cleaned regularly, this is a job that should be done in private using one's OWN truck keys.

Message.Title: Tegra 3 issues?
Message.Msg: As I have been stating for a couple of months now I have been trying to find a working demo of the Nexus 7. So far, nada. I ran across this fairly non-technical article yesterday. As you know the tablet is powered by the Tegra 3. There were two points that stood out from the article (the article was a mostly glowing review of the tablet) "Carrying around the Nexus 7 everyday quickly revealed one of the Nexus's weaknesses. At an advertised 9.5 hours, the Nexus 7's battery is fine - beyond fine maybe - but I never got that much juice out of it, and it's standby lasts nowhere near Google's advertised 300 hours. The Nexus is more inline with a phone battery than an iPad battery, which means you'll have to charge it every day." This is interesting because the design of the Tegra 3 is a quad core processor and then one slower baby core that runs at a much lower clock speed and sips energy. Wasn't the superior battery life a selling point of ARM? Here's another iPad overheating when playing games issue with this tablet. "This has the same internals as the Ouya, and can handle heavy processing pretty well - though I never experienced it, some users have noticed touch response dropping during intense gaming sessions, an unfortunate side effect of what looks to be overheating." The Tegra 3 is positioned by ARM as a goal so high that there is no way that Intel can reach it. After reading this article I think that the bar has been knocked down a few places and in the real world ARM isn't as far ahead as they claim to be. http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/16/the-nexus-7-review

Message.Title: Haswell gonna blow Y'all away !!!!
Message.Msg: Since Microsoft’s ARM announcement, Intel has shown they have the low power chops with Medfield and AMD has surprised everyone with how efficient Trinity is on battery life. Still, Microsoft is banking on ARM devices to be successful for maximum profits even though they could always fall back on Intel in mobility and even AMD if they decided to enter the space. Keep in mind that Microsoft’s decision to invest in ARM came at the cost of not investing additional functionality and usage models into the desktop, and therefore Microsoft needs to get something out of ARM to assure this payoff. Microsoft must be successful with ARM architectures or risk competing toe to toe with Apple and Samsung, that is, unless Intel’s 14nm Haswell blows everyone away.

Topic.Title: Tegra 3 issues?

Message.Msg: How much $$ are the INtel tablets ??? Is Intel competing in the $199 market ? Not yet, but they will. All I am saying is that the ARM being two years ahead of Intel statement that the ARMH CEO made just doesn't seem to be true. The Tegra 3 looks to be a nice processor, but the fact remains that a 12.5 day standby time which in reality turns out to be a one to two day standby time I get kinda skeptical. If those are the real world specs that Intel must meet to be in the game it suddenly looks much easier. Most of the tablets on the market don't have replaceable batteries. I know people who can't live without their tablets and will buy a new one when the battery starts to die. But, in general I am wondering how many original iPad owners there are who put up with worsening battery performance. Just because they shelled out $500 at one point will the do it again? The article made a good point about how portable the Nexus 7 was, and how little effort went into using it. I am thinking that smaller and cheaper and larger and more powerful is where the industry is heading. Going from 10" to 7" is something that the industry can do especially with jaded consumers who don't care to take another $500+ trip to the Apple store. For those who demand power I can see them moving into Core processors with larger screens. They can game for a few hours between charges which may be good enough for them.

Topic.Title: Apple moving to Intel IMO

Message.Msg: I see Apple as a company reluctant to change a formula that is working. That being said five years from now if they don't make the move to Intel I think this will be the time period they look back on and think "Man, we should have done that."

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: 'Medfield with Intel's process lead is only at par with current ARM offerings on the power-performance map. With the growing manufacturing momentum behind the ARM camp, this is unlikely to change. Otellini's claims on extending the process lead don't check out.' A single-core first generation in-order Atom competes successfully with the latest dual-core ARM out-of-order chips. How do you think the brand new second generation version will do on the most advanced 22nm process ? There will also be dual-core and quad-core variants with the latter to become the premier tablet performance chip. Sure Samsung and Apple will survive with their proprietary in-house chips but the other ARM chip merchant vendors may be in for a bit of trouble ;-). 'Likely scenario -- Intel remains a fringe player in mobile for a while then gracefully exits as it has done on countless projects before this that are outside of its comfort zone.' Likely scenario -- Intel eventually makes ARM the AMD of the mobile world ;-).

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: A single core Medfield clocked at 1.6GHz consumes as much power as a dual core A5 clocked at 800MHz. How is Intel going to cut back on power/core? Process benefits are more or less equal in both lanes.
